Caption: Figure 4: The red (gray in B&W) point denotes the “center” of a crowded region. From left to right, the locations of center defined by arithmetic mean, spatial median and VNSM are shown respectively.
Mention:
mean can be outside a given region if the n object points 
form concave boundaries (Fig. 4 (left)). Masse et al. 
discussed other location estimators, e.g., Tukey median, 
the n object points inside a crowded region are candidates. 
However, the center defined by spatial median may lie on 
the boundary for some concave shapes (Fig. 4 (middle)). As 
we have discussed in the previous section, skeletons are 
often defined as “center lines” or “medial axes”. Therefore, 
visual centeredness, i.e., skeletons should not lie on the 
boundary of the object, is often desirable. 
We introduce a Valence Normalized Spatial Median 
(VNSM) algorithm to compute the center of a crowded 
region. The key concept is to normalize by the valence of a 
point (vertex), giving us: 
penalizes boundary points which have smaller valences 
than interior points. As a result, the estimated center is 
attracted towards the middle of the region (Fig. 4 (right)).  
To reduce computational cost of computing square root 
for Euclidean distance and division we modify Equation (2) 
to Equation (3). Since n is a constant, removing n does not 
affect the value for which the expression attains its 
minimum. 
Fig. 4 (right) shows the center obtained by using VNSM. 
We also tested our approach on various poses of the 
same model. Fig. 14 shows several models that were 
modified to represent different poses, along with their 
skeletons. Depending on the extent of difference between 
poses, our algorithm produced a small dissimilarity 
measure for the different models. For example, chain code 
based measure gives scores between 0.06 and 0.19 for 
various poses of 3D shapes, like the ones shown in Fig. 14, 
showing some ability to discriminate between the pairs. 
Whereas, a measure based on graph structure and relative 
lengths of segments produces scores of 0’s for both.
